reviews: Have you ever thought about other men when you're having sex with me? Yes, Chairman MaoI giggled

65Very primitive and very messy, but that's kind of just the charm of it.Although I felt distanced at the start, once your on its wavelength, you get much more from this.The final 'short film' out of the three is by far the best, and I would honestly wish that the it whole runtime. Its clunky and awkward but captures something really precious. A number of very tender and beautiful moments, but like all things in this film, some work better than others.Would recommend to any Araki fans.

iconic, genius, hilarious, quirky, arty, so deeply gay in every way. and also i didnt finish it lol, would like to rewatch with someone."Four queer stories revolve around crimes of passion, matricide, vampires and two college roommates, connected by a filmmaker's mockumentary."
asian-american queer cinema never lets me down

This review may contain spoilers. I can handle the truth. Mom of Quentin Lee: "when he came out, he had a very peculiar reaction to me. he was disappointed that I didn't cry, or burst out at him. tbh, he's a drama queen and addicted to trauma. I was just happy for‚Ä¶
i wish that the fourth short film had been the whole movie. not to discredit the first 3 but the artsy student film vibe isn‚Äôt my thing

Stumbled on a tape of this at We Luv Video and really enjoyed it. Was a bit uneven at times but coming from an amateur director with limited resources was overall pretty well done. Cool concept, interesting stories and visuals. A+
hated that bitch at the end but this was cute!

Lee creates a parallel universe in which to situate his own early shorts, complete with an invented epidemic killing off the gay men around him. A queer retelling of queer artmaking and lifeliving. Absolutely stunning.
i mean... whatever this film is about...just trust, you'd understand everything by the last film an actual good movie, it's fun to interpret it :))
So much ingenuity, so much spite, so much reconciliation. Letterboxd grossly undersells this in its synopsis. Peep the UCLA Melnitz jump scare lol
my brother made a movie called "Those Other Days" but it's not on letterboxd so this is as close as we'll get for now

For me, the problem with Minh's films has always been that he usually has a lot of resources to go full vision, so, like all of the up and coming directors, he tended to include all of the shots he shot in the finished cut. That leads to his movie are full of moments where he hold onto a shot just a bit too long for no apparent reason. As a result, the story occasionally veers off course. Even after‚Ä¶
